Narrative_Description: Italians had thrown money out into the streets, since it wouldn't be able to save them for the virus
Motive_Description: Show hopelessness of the Italians
Summary: An old image from a robbery in Venezuela was spread as a picture from Italy during the pandemic with the claim that Italians had tossed their money into the streets in despair.

Title: No! These Aren’t Visuals Of Mass Graves In Italy But, A Scene From A Science Fiction Movie!
Narrative_Description: Deaths due to the COVID-19 pandemic had led to Italy creating mass graves
Motive_Description: Evoke fear among people over the deaths caused by COVID-19
Summary: A scene from a movie, Pandemic, was spread with the claim that the video depicted mass graves in Italy.

Title: FACT CHECK: Clip Of A 2013 Korean Movie “Flu” Gets Viral As Visuals From Italy.
Narrative_Description: Mass deaths caused by COVID-19 in Italy had led to dead bodies being crane-lifted out of stadiums.
Motive_Description: Evoke fear among people over the deaths caused by COVID-19
Summary: A scene from the movie, Flu, was spread with the claim that the video showed dead bodies being lifted out of stadiums by cranes.

Title: Hot baths, hot hand dryers and Other heat will NOT kill coronavirus
Narrative_Description: Hot baths and hand dryers can kill COVID-19
Motive_Description: Promote False Hope about fake measures to prevent COVID-19
Key_Words: Coronavirus, bath, hand dryer, kill, heat
Summary: Mary Wilson, a lecturer from Koforidua Technical University in Ghana, appeared in a video falsely claiming that hot baths and hand dryers could kill coronavirus

Title: No evidence ibuprofen makes Covid-19 worse, say experts
Narrative_Description: Claims that ibuprofen makes the new coronavirus multiply faster and should not be taken
Motive_Description: Taking ibuprofen to treat COVID-19 could be fatal
Summary: Facebook posts in South Africa falsely claimed that researchers from Vienna found that taking ibuprofen to treat COVID-19 could be fatal

Title: BCG vaccine used in Africa could reduce symptoms, but not ‘cure’ or ‘vaccine’ for Covid-19
Narrative_Description: Claims that a tuberculosis (TB) vaccine used in some African countries is being considered as “a possible vaccine” for the coronavirus
Motive_Description: Create hope that Africans are already vaccinated against COVID-19
Key_Words: Coronavirus, BCG, vaccine, cure, Africa, TB
Summary: A South African radio presenter falsly claimed that BCG, a mandatory TB vaccine in South Africa, was being investigated as a 'vaccine' for COVID-19

Title: Fruit, veg and ‘natural herbs’ can’t cure Covid-19, produce vaccine
Narrative_Description: Herbs, fruit and vegetables can treat Covid-19
Motive_Description: Promote False Hope about herbal COVID-19 remedies
Source_Description: Nigerian traditional ruler Oba Adeyeye Enitan Ogunwusi
Key_Words: Coronavirus, fruit, vegetable, herb, treat, vaccine
Summary: Nigerian traditional ruler Oba Adeyeye Enitan Ogunwusi posted a video claiming that fruits, vegetables, and herbs could be used to treat COVID-19 and that a vaccine could be derived from herbal remedies

Title: No, tea does not cure Covid-19
Narrative_Description: Claims a Chinese “hero doctor” found evidence that chemicals in tea “would significantly decrease the impact” of the Covid-19
Motive_Description: Promote False Hope that African tea will cure COVID-19
Key_Words: Coronavirus, tea, China, doctor, Li Wenliang
Summary: In a post adapted for African audiences, users claimed that that a Chinese doctor found that chemicals in an African tea could cure COVID-19

Title: No, African leaders haven’t endorsed Madagascar’s ‘herbal medicine’ as coronavirus vaccine
Narrative_Description: Claims African leaders have endorsed a Madagascan “vaccine” for Covid-19, COVID-Organics
Motive_Description: Promote False Hope about a Madagascan cure for COVID-19 being endorsed by Other leaders in Africa
Key_Words: Coronavirus, vaccine, Madagascar, Africa, leaders, endorse
Summary: Facebook posts falsely claimed that African leaders met and endorsed a Madagascan 'vaccine' for COVID-19, Covid-Organics

Title: No, edible plant known as ewedu, bush okra and jute can’t stop coronavirus spreading in the body
Narrative_Description: Molokhia leaves help curb reproduction of coronavirus
Motive_Description: Create hope about fake cures
Key_Words: Coronavirus, prevent, ewedu, zinc, good news
Summary: A claim originally shared in the Middle East also circulated on WhatsApp in Nigeria, claiming that eating the African plant ewedu could stop coronavirus from spreading in the body

Title: Ginger, turmeric won’t cure coronavirus or Other diseases
Narrative_Description: Claims a mixture of natural ingredients can be used as “Natural Antibiotics” for “all kinds of sickness”, including Covid-19
Motive_Description: Natural ingredients can be used to treat COVID-19
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Fiji, Nigeria, ginger, turmeric, natural, antibiotic
Summary: A Facebook post originally from Fiji circulated in Nigeria, claiming that a "Natural Antibiotic" could be made from ginger, turmeric, and Other ingredients to treat diseases including COVID-19

Title: বিশ্ব স্বাস্থ্য সংস্থা কি বলেছে 'অজু করোনা ভাইরাসের সর্বোত্তম ঔষধ'?
Narrative_Description: Ablution is the best medicine for coronavirus' - a false statement spread by some online portals in the name of the World Health Organization
Motive_Description: Create hope that by washing hands and face 5 times a day just or Wudhu in Islam, will help prevent catching coronavirus
Summary: Several news portals reported that wudhu (islam way of ding ablution) is the best medicine for coronavirus. But there has been no specific statement from the World Health Organization or any Other responsible body on "5 times hand-face washing".

Title: মিডিয়ায় প্রকাশিত খবরে বিভ্রান্তিকর তথ্য আছে: ডা. তারেক
Narrative_Description: Research reports on the use of ivermectin and doxycycline in people with covid have shown good results.
Motive_Description: Create hope for a cure
Key_Words: Ivermectin, doxycycline, Dr. Fabric, research, misleading
Summary: Several news portals reported that there is a promising research using ivermectin, doxycycline to treat coronavirus patients conducted by Dr. Tareq Alam, a thoracic specialist at Bangladesh Medical College Hospital. He corrected the reports, saying that they never conducted any research and the combination of ivermectin and doxycyclinea is used as an experimental treatment.

Title: মোহাম্মাদ নাসিমের মৃত্যুর গুজব
Narrative_Description: Rumors of the death of Mohammad Nasim in social media
Motive_Description: Have people think that Mohammed Nasim, Bangladesh Awami League politician, have died from coronary heart disease.
Summary: Bangladesh Awami League politician, Mohammed Nasim, was reported to have died in Facebook. At the time of fact checking, his condition wasn't changed. He died a few days later on June 13.

Title: This video shows patients who were evacuated from a hospital in Pakistan after a fire broke out
Narrative_Description: Claim a video shows coronavirus patients who were moved outside a hospital in Pakistan because of an overflow of patients
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about the overflow of COVID-19 patients in hospitals
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Pakistan, hospital, patients, Rawalpindi, space
Summary: A video was shared in Pakistan with the false claim that it showed COVID-19 patients having to be moved outside of a hospital in Rawalpindi, Pakistan due to a lack of space. The video actually shows patients evacuated after a fire

Title: খাসির মাংসে করোনা ভাইরাস পাওয়ার ভুয়া খবর প্রচার
Narrative_Description: "Coronavirus is found in castrated meat!" A news was published in some online portals of Bangladesh last March
Motive_Description: Evoke fear of consuming meat, esp the castrated meat
Summary: "Coronavirus is found in castrated meat!" A news was published in some online portals of Bangladesh last March. It then shared in social media. The fake news supposedly originated from India.

Title: করোনাভাইরাস: না, দেবী শেঠি ২২টি জরুরি পরামর্শ দেননি
Narrative_Description: Devi Prasad Shetty, an Indian cardiac surgeon and entrepreneur, was reported to give 22 advice to survive coronavirus for a year
Motive_Description: Create hope by giving tips on how to survive coronavirus
Key_Words: Devi Shetty, 22 advice, survive Coronavirus, a year
Summary: Devi Prasad Shetty, an Indian cardiac surgeon and entrepreneur, was reported to give 22 advice to survive coronavirus for a year. But most of the 22 advice that have been circulated in Bangladeshi Mediaare fabricated.

Title: হোমিওপ্যাথি ওষুধ 'আর্সেনিকাম অ্যালবাম ৩০' কি করোনাভাইরাস প্রতিরোধ করে?
Narrative_Description: Homoeopathy for prevention of Coronavirus infections
Motive_Description: Create hope by consuming homoeopathy can prevent catching coronavirus
Summary: "Homeopathy to prevent corona virus! Corona will disappear if you take it for three days in a row" - a news was published on a Bangladeshi portal on May 3. Previously, a government guidelines in India claim that the drug Arsenicum Album-30 helps prevent Covid-19. There is no scientific research to prove this claim.

Title: মার্কিন গবেষণা কি বলেছে করোনাভাইরাস প্রতিরোধে হিজাব সহায়ক?
Narrative_Description: False news circulated saying that a US study say hijab is helpful in preventing coronavirus
Motive_Description: Perhaps urging people to start wearing hijab
Summary: News portals reported that one American researcher found that hijab helps prevent coronavirus, quoting an US media, The Conversation. Anna Payla, the reseacher, never mentioned anything regarding niqab as the solution. Instead, she said that "the niqab alone is not sufficient protection against influenza-like viruses because it is not airtight."

Title: No, Sultan of Sokoto didn’t say Nigeria’s first Covid-19 case was faked
Narrative_Description: The claim is that the sultan, Muhammadu Sa’adu Abubakar III, who is considered the spiritual leader of the country’s Muslims, said Nigeria’s first case of Covid-19 was a hoax
Motive_Description: Promote false infomration about Nigerian sultan Abubakar III
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Nigeria, sultan, Abubakar III, hoax, first
Summary: Facebook posts claimed that Nigeria's sultan, Abubakar III, said the country's first COVID-19 case was a hoax

Title: Three months’ free rent in Kenya during Covid-19 crisis? No, announcement fake
Narrative_Description: Claims Kenya is providing 3 months of free rent as a result of COVID-19
Motive_Description: Criticize the Nigerian government for not giving free rent like the Kenyan government
Summary: Facebook posts in Nigeria spread a fake document from the government of Kenya claiming that Kenyans would get 3 months of free rent and asking Nigeria to do the same

Title: No, you can’t get coronavirus from eating chicken
Narrative_Description: You can get coronavirus from eating chicken
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about the presence of COVID-19 in food
Summary: Using a screenshot of a post originally shared in India, users in Nigeria falsely claimed that COVID-19 could be transmitted by eating chicken

Title: Sudanese minister wearing face mask in meeting with Chinese ambassador? Image photoshopped
Narrative_Description: Claim a photo shows a Sudanese minister wearing a surgical mask while speaking to a Chinese official
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about the spread of COVID-19
Summary: A photo from February was photoshopped to make it look like a Sudanese minister wore a face mask while speaking to a Chinese ambassador.

Title: No, Kenyan newspaper didn’t report coronavirus patient’s stay at Weston Hotel
Narrative_Description: Claims the Kenyan newspaper Saturday Nation reported that a COVID-19 patient stayed for 2 days in the Weston Hotel in Nairobi
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about the movement of COVID-19 patients
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Kenya, Nairobi, Weston, Saturday Nation
Summary: A fake photo of the front page of the Kenyan newspaper Saturday Nation circulated on Facebook with the false story that a COVID-19 patient spent two days in the Weston Hotel

Title: Photos not of coronavirus outbreak – and virus not ‘unknown’, fatal in ‘few seconds’
Narrative_Description: Claims the coronavirus is an “unknown virus” that kills in “under few seconds”, and is punishment  for the Chinese government’s alleged clampdown on Muslims in the country
Motive_Description: Promote false claims about the origin and nature of COVID-19
Summary: A widely shared Facebook post in Nigeria claimed that coronavirus is an “unknown virus” that kills in “under few seconds”, and is punishment  for the Chinese government’s alleged clampdown on Muslims in the country

Title: Hong Kong streets empty of protestors after coronavirus? No, photo of Wuhan, China
Narrative_Description: Claims two photos show the streets of Hong Kong before and after the outbreak of Covid-19, with the after photo being empty
Motive_Description: Claim that COVID-19 has quelled protests in Hong Kong
Summary: Photos posted on Facebook in South Africa claimed to show the streets of Hong Kong before and after COVID-19 with the second photo being empty, but the second photo is actually of Wuhan, China

Title: New coronavirus hasn’t killed millions – and photo from art project
Narrative_Description: Claims a photo shows millions of dead COVID-19 victims in China and asks who created the virus
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about the severity of COVID-19
Key_Words: Coronavirus, China, bodies, death, millions, create, invent, destruction
Summary: A 2014 photo spread in Nigeria with the claim that it showed millions of dead COVID-19 victims in China, asking who invented or created the virus

Title: No evidence Obasanjo said there was no coronavirus in Nigeria
Narrative_Description: Claims Former Nigerian president Olusegun Obasanjo has said there are no cases of coronavirus in the country
Motive_Description: Attribute false claims to former Nigerian president Olusegun Obasanjo
Summary: Articles circulated with the false claim that former Nigerian president Olusegun Obasanjo said there were no COVID-19 cases in Nigeria

Title: Citizen TV reported Kenya’s ‘second’ coronavirus case, at MultiMediaUniversity? No
Narrative_Description: Claims Kenya confirmed its second COVID-19 case at the MultiMediaUniversity of Kenya
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about the spread of COVID-19 in Kenya
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Kenya, second, case, MMU, Citizen TV
Summary: A photo made to look like a Citizen TV headline falsely claimed that Kenya's second COVID-19 case was confirmed within hours of the first at the MultiMediaUniversity of Kenya

Title: Kenyans crowding in churches despite coronavirus ban? No, photos years old
Narrative_Description: Claims photos show Kenyans crowding into churches despite COVID-19 ban
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about Kenyans flaunting COVID-19 lockdown measures
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Kenya, church, ban, gathering, lockdown
Summary: Photos circulated on Facebook with the claim that they showed Kenyans gathering in churches despite the COVID-19 lockdown. The photos were actually from 2014 and 2016

Title: No, Putin hasn’t put 800 lions, hyenas on Russian streets to keep people in homes during coronavirus pandemic
Narrative_Description: Claims Russian President Putin released 800 Lions And Hyenas In Russian Streets To Keep Everyone Home
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about Emergency Responses to COVID-19 abroad
Summary: Old photos were circulated in Nigeria with the false claim that they showed Russia, where President Putin released 800 lions and hyenas to keep people at home during the COVID-19 lockdown

Title: WHO still recommends self-isolation and social distancing to prevent COVID-19 transmission
Narrative_Description: Claim that the World Health Organization (WHO) has rescinded its advice which urges isolation for COVID-19 patients and social distancing in public
Motive_Description: Encourage idea of COVID-19 as a conspiracy, claim that prevention measures are not necessary
Key_Words: Coronavirus, WHO, advice, isolation, social distancing, rescind
Summary: A false claim originating on Twitter stated that the WHO made a 'U turn,' rescinding advice for COVID-19 patients to isolate and for social distancing

Title: Was President Trump Scared On Podium When A Man Shouted Coronavirus
Narrative_Description: President Trump was startled when a man rushed to stage and shouted coronavirus
Motive_Description: Intended to evoke humor
Summary: A video from 2016 was shared as Trump being scared when a man rushed stage and shouted coronavirus at him.

Title: No, WHO Did Not Advise Public To Stop Eating Bakery Items!
Narrative_Description: WHO advised people to stop shopping for and consuming bakery items
Motive_Description: Make people think COVID-19 can spread through bakery items
Summary: A false graphic was shared on social Mediawith the claim that bakery items were spreading COVID-19 and people should stop consuming them.

Title: No, Famous Baby Model Anahita Hashemzadeh Is Not Suffering From COVID19
Narrative_Description: Child model and actor, Anahita Hashemzadeh, was suffering from COVID-19
Motive_Description: Evoke fear by making people think a child actor had the virus
Summary: An image of a child was shared as that of child model and actor, Anahita Hashemzadeh, with the claim that she had COVID-19.

Title: FACT CHECK: No, This Is Not The Image Of Hapless Italian President Crying While Addressing The Nation.
Narrative_Description: Italian President was crying because of the COVID-19 situation in Italy
Motive_Description: Show the despair of the Italian President at the COVID-19 situation
Summary: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro's image crying was circulated as that of the Italian President crying due to the COVID-19 situation in Italy.

Title: Jon Snow Has Not Contracted COVID-19 After Returning From Iran In February
Narrative_Description: British journalist Jon Snow had contracted the coronavirus after visiting Iran
Motive_Description: Make people think Jon Snow had COVID-19
Summary: A false rumor was spread claiming British journalist, Jon Snow, had contracted COVID-19 after traveling to Iran in February.

Title: Consuming Alcohol Cannot Protect You From Coronavirus
Narrative_Description: Drinking alcohol can cure COVID-19
Motive_Description: Make people believe that drinking alcohol will cure COVID--19
Summary: A viral prescription on a "Saint Luke's Hospital" letterhead claimed that drinking alcohol can kill the coronavirus.

Title: 7-Year-Old Image Of Ship Wreck In Italy Falsely Shared As Corona Virus Victims
Narrative_Description: COVID-19 had caused numerous deaths in Italy
Motive_Description: Evoke fear of the virus
Summary: A 7-year old image of deaths caused by a shipwreck was shared as deaths caused by the novel coronavirus

Title: WHO Did Not Snub Sri Lanka Citing Inadequate Measures In Response To COVID-19 Pandemic
Narrative_Description: Sri Lanka's COVID-19 response was not enough according to WHO
Motive_Description: Make people think that their government's response to COVID-19 was inadequate
Key_Words: Coronavirus, WHO, Sri Lanka, inadequate response
Summary: A statement by the WHO South East Asia regional director asking Sri Lanka to scale up measures against the virus were misconstrued and circulated as WHO saying Sri Lanka had an inadequate response to COVID-19

Title: Did The Last COVID19 Infected Patient In Wuhan Get Discharged..? Here’s The Truth!
Narrative_Description: Wuhan was celebrating because the last COVID-19 patient was discharged from the hospital
Motive_Description: Spread confidence in China's handling of COVID-19
Summary: While cases in Wuhan had dropped drastically, the post was promoting the false idea that there were no patients of COVID-19 in Wuhan anymore.

Title: Eid Prayers On Chinese Street In 2019 Shared As Muslim Community Praying For Coronavirus
Narrative_Description: Muslims in China were praying for COVID-19 to go
Motive_Description: Rare instance of showing the Muslim community in a positive light
Summary: An old video of an Eid prayer was circulated with the claim that Muslims in China were praying for COVID-19 to be eradicated.

Title: Suspected Coronavirus Infected Girl From Badulla, Discharged After Tested Negative For The Virus…
Narrative_Description: A girl was suspected of having COVID-19 after coming back from China and was admitted in Badulla hospital
Motive_Description: Spread fear of positive COVID cases
Summary: A girl who had returned from Wuhan was tested negative for the novel coronavirus but rumors were circulating that she was infected.

Title: Did Chinese President Visit A Muslim Mosque Recently? Here’s The Truth!
Narrative_Description: Xi Jinping had visited a mosque to ask Muslims to pray for China
Motive_Description: Make people think Xi Jinping had asked Muslims to pray for the country
Key_Words: Coronavirus, China, Xi Jinping, mosque, Muslims, pray
Summary: An old video from 2016 of XJP visiting a mosque in China was repurposed and made viral with the claim that he had gone to a mosque to ask Muslims to pray for the COVID-19 situation in China

Title: Sri Lankan Undergrad Student’s Photo Shared With False Narrative Linking Him To Corona Virus
Narrative_Description: A student had come in contact with patient zero in Sri Lanka and was hiding
Motive_Description: Spread fear that there was a COVID positive patient hiding
Summary: A false rumor was spread with the image of a student and claimed that he was infected with COVID-19 and was hiding so as to not get tested.

Title: China Didn’t Construct A Hospital In Just 2 Days Instead Of The Proposed 6 Days. Here’s The Truth…
Narrative_Description: China had built a hospital in two days
Motive_Description: Make the Chinese government's response seem great
Summary: A newly opened hospital was an extended wing of Huanggang Central Hospital, scheduled to open in May 2020. A dedicated work force made the empty building into a fully operational hospital within two days, which was mistaken as the Huoshenshan Hospital proposed to be constructed in 6 days.

Title: Mélange Of Unrelated Videos From China Shared Misleadingly In Context To Recent Corona Virus Outbreak.
Narrative_Description: COVID-19 was causing people to howl and bite like dogs
Motive_Description: Spread fear about strange symptoms associated with COVID-19
Summary: A mix of different unrelated videos from China were merged to create a misleading video shared in context to COVID-19.

Title: CANULAR: Le port du masque facial ne favorise pas la pénétration du coronavirus dans le cerveau
Narrative_Description: Claims that bringing a face mask facilitates the penetration of coronavirus inside the brain
Motive_Description: Spark the fear of carrying a face mask by claiming that it is dangerous
Summary: Several Facebook accounts in Mali and francophone Africa shared the news that carrying a fae masks could facilitate the virus penetration inside the brain

Title: FAUX: Vladimir Poutine n’a ni fait une commande de COVID-Organics ni demandé aux Africains de se méfier de l’OMS
Narrative_Description: Claims that Russian President Vladimir Putin has adopted COVID-Organics as a remedy against COVID-19 in Russia and warned Africans to mistrust WHO
Motive_Description: Undermine trust in WHO while promoting the use of COVID-Organics
Key_Words: Coronavirus, COVID-Organics, Madagscar, Russia, Putin, WHO, mistrust
Summary: The news went viral in francophone Africa that President Putin had bought COVID-Organics from Madagascar to use it as a remedy against COVID-19 in Russia, and had warned Africans to mistrust WHO officials

Title: FAUX: Le coronavirus n’est pas dépisté avec des lunettes en Chine
Narrative_Description: Claims that a new technology has been developed in China that uses glasses to immediately test people for COVID-19 and understand if they're postive
Motive_Description: Make people believe that a new technology can allow to test people for COVID-19 very quickly and efficiently
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Burundi, glasses, China, test, technology
Summary: The claim went viral in Burundi that a new technology had been developed in China, allowing doctors to test people for COVID-19 simply using glasses with specific, innovative lenses. This was, however, untrue.

Title: FAUX: Le ministre burundais de la santé n’est pas atteint du coronavirus
Narrative_Description: Claim that Burundi's Health Minister became infected with COVID-19
Motive_Description: Criticize the government for denying the coronavirus crisis and now being at risk because of this
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Burundi, Health, Minister, infected, Thaddée Ndikumana
Summary: The news was shared on Facebook and Twitter that Thaddée Ndikumana, Burundi's Health Minister, had become infected with COVID-19 and had travelled to Kenya to be cured, even though he was in the country for Other reasons

Title: INTOX: Ceci est une image hors-contexte qui n’illustre pas les conditions de traitement des patients dans les hôpitaux centrafricains
Narrative_Description: Picture showing terrible conditions of patients in hospitals of the Central African Republic
Motive_Description: Criticize CAF's incumbent government by claiming it leaves hospitals in terrible conditions
Key_Words: Central African Republic, hospitals, patients, terrible, conditions, Bangui
Summary: A picture taken during a conflict in 2013 was taken out of context and pushed by members of the opposition in the Central African Republic to claim it was showing a hospital in Bangui, and that the government was leaving hospitals (and their patients) in terrible conditions

Title: FALSE: Getting a new tattoo is not a cure for COVID-19
Narrative_Description: Claim there exists a new tattoo that can cure coronavirus
Motive_Description: Advertise a tattoo business by claiming one of its tattoos can cure COVID-19
Summary: A Nairobi-based tattoo business shared a post on Instagram claiming a new tattoo could cure COVID-19

Title: INTOX: Le gouvernement centrafricain n’a pas suspendu les vols d’Air France reliant Paris et Bangui
Narrative_Description: Public statement by the government claiming the new cases of COVID-19 in RCA are due to the reopening of the M'Poko airport
Motive_Description: Criticize airline companies and foreigners, by claiming they are contributing to bringing COVID-19 to the Central African Republic
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Central African Republic, airport, airline, M'Poko
Summary: A fake public statement, supposedly released by the government of the Central African Republic and circulating on WhatsApp, claimed that the government attributed the new cases of COVID-19 in the country to the reopening of the M'Poko international airport

Title: জাফরুল্লাহর গণস্বাস্থ্যের উদ্ভাবিত প্রযুক্তি কি ইউরোপে অনুমোদন পেয়েছে?
Narrative_Description: Dr. Jafrullah's public health technology has been approved in Europe and the first Bangladeshi researcher, Bijan Kumar, invented the antibody test method in 2003.
Motive_Description: Pride of a nation and False Hope that a technology to cure coronavirus has been found
Key_Words: Dr. Jafrullah, public health technology, approved, Europe
Summary: Online portals reported "Dr. Zafarullah's Public Health Innovation Technology Approved in Europe" with a link to UK's The Independent media. The link is actually telling of the success of a European diagnostic firm (Abbott) in the antibody test and the approval of the US and the European Union to conduct large-scale antibody tests. Also, anOther success reported in the news portal is Bijan Kumar, the first Bangladeshi researcher who invented the antibody test method in 2003. The practice of testing antibodies in humans after virus attacks has existed long before 2003.

Title: Aucune production d’un traitement contre la Covid-19 (APPI-19) n’est imminente en RDC
Primary_Country: Congo, the Democratic Republic of the
Narrative_Description: Rumors that the DRC will soon produce its own treatment against COVID-19, APPI-19, thanks to Dr. Jérôme Munyangi
Motive_Description: Foster national pride by claiming the DRC has created its own remedy against COVID-19
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Congo, Jérôme Munyangi, cure, APPI-19
Summary: The news started circulating in June in the DRC that the country would produce its own treatment against COVID-19 thanks to Congolese doctor Jérôme Munyangi, even though this was never confirmed

Title: করোনাভাইরাস মোকাবিলা: বাংলাদেশে কি সুরক্ষা সরঞ্জামের ঘাটতি নেই?
Narrative_Description: Prime Minister and the Health Minister have claimed that there is no shortage of safety equipment for health workers in the country to deal with coronavirus, while legitimate Mediareported Otherwise.
Motive_Description: Trying to convey that the government is taking control of the pandemic
Key_Words: Shortage, PPE, Prime Minister, Health Minister
Summary: The Prime Minister and the Health Minister have claimed that there is no shortage of safety equipment for health workers in the country to deal with coronavirus. But respectable, independent Mediasuch as BBC Bangla, Jamuna TV, The Business Standard reported Otherwise.

Title: RDC : Cette liste contenant des remèdes contre la COVID-19 est un faux
Primary_Country: Congo, the Democratic Republic of the
Narrative_Description: Picture showing a supposed medical protocol against COVID-19, with pharmaceuticals including chloroquine
Motive_Description: Make people believe there is one single "formula" doctors use to treat patients against COVID-19
Summary: The picture of a piece of paper with the names of some pharmaceuticals (including chloroquine) written on it, was shared on Facebook with the claim it showed the cure used by doctors against COVID-19, while the actual medical protocol depends on the gravity of the case and the type of patient and cannot be fixed

Title: Faux, les années académique et scolaire n’ont pas été déclarées blanches en RDC
Primary_Country: Congo, the Democratic Republic of the
Narrative_Description: Claim that both universities and schools across the DRC have lost a year because of COVID-19
Motive_Description: Have people believe that because of the coronavirus emergency the academic year for university and the school year for schools have been annulled by the Ministry of Education
Summary: The news went viral in the DRC that because of the coronavirus emergency, the academic year for university and the school year for schools have been annulled by the Ministry of Education

Title: ভুল চিকিৎসা: করোনা থেকে মুক্তি পেতে গরম পানি, লেবুর রস, সরিষার ভাপ
Narrative_Description: A Bangladeshi has come up with a "100% sure cure formula" for coronavirus at home.
Motive_Description: Have people believe in false concoction
Key_Words: MS Media, hot water, lemon juice, mustard steam, get rid
Summary: A video has gone viral on Facebook claiming that a Bangladeshi has come up with a "100% guaranteed treatment formula" for coronavirus at home. The formula is two large lemon juice, two and a half glasses of water, 10 cardamom, 10 pieces of cinnamon, 7 cloves of crushed garlic, half a poya, half a crushed, and 2 teaspoons of pure mustard oil and heat in a pot.

Title: এটি কভিড-১৯ এর টেস্টিং কিট, ভ্যাকসিন নয়
Narrative_Description: A covid-19 testing kit manufactured by a Korean pharmaceutical company is being promoted on Facebook as covid-19 vaccine.

Summary: A WhatsApp message saying that coronavirus lives on the hands for 10 minutes therefore putting hand sanitizer in the pocket can be preventative, said UNICEF. The UN arm never released such advisory.

Summary: A news outlet broke a story saying that experts think that tilapia fish can spread coronavirus. It then widely shared in Facebook.

Summary: A photo was manipulated to make it look like Karanja Kibicho, Kenya’s interior ministry principal secretary, held up his middle finger while talking about 'idiots' who violated the COVID-19 curfew in Kenya. Kibicho actually held up his index finger

Title: No, Madagascar president didn’t say in interview that WHO offered him $20m to poison Covid-19 remedy

Title: Nigeria has more than 8,000 confirmed cases of Covid-19

Motive_Description: Amplify the notion that Nieria has no COVID-19 cases
Summary: A photo shared over 37K times on Facebook in Nigeria shows a man holding a sign, photoshopped to say, "No coronavirus in Nigeria If you believe share." Nigeria had over 8,000 COVID-19 cases at the time this article was written

Title: No, Nigerian minister didn’t say 17.3 million children were fed as part of Covid-19 relief

Summary: A Facebook post attributed a fake quote to Sadiya Farouq, Nigeria’s minister of humanitarian affairs, in which she said 17.3 million children were fed as part of a COVID-19 relief effort. In fact, the program targeted only 3.1 million households and the ministry denied this quote

Title: DRC’s Mukwege didn’t say he resigned from Covid-19 committees because he ‘can’t dirty my Nobel prize for money’

Summary: A story claimed that Dr. Denis Mukwege resigned from the DRC's Multisectoral Coronavirus Response Committee because he couldn't 'dirty' his Nobel prize money, but he never said this

Title: Dean Koontz predicted 2019 coronavirus in 1981 novel? No

Summary: A conspiracy theory which has circulated in multiple countries also appeared in South Africa, falsely claiming that a 1981 book by Dean Koontz described and predicted COVID-19

Title: PARTLY FALSE: The USD 25 million that Uganda has received for COVID-19 relief is not meant for distribution to every adult

Summary: Facebook posts falsely claimed that Kakamega Governor Wycliffe Oparanya was giving cash relief to Kenyans in distress as a result of COVID-19, asking them to send financial information via Facebook messenger

Title:
This Video Does Not Show Vladimir Putin's Daughter Receiving COVID-19 Shots

https://www.boomlive.in/fake-news/this-video-does-not-show-vladimir-putins-daughter-receiving-covid-19-shots-9270
Narrative_Description: Putin's daughter getting a dose of the first COVID-19 vaccine

Title: Kerala Plane Crash: Malappuram DC Denies 40 Passengers Tested COVID-19 Positive

Title: Delhi's Killer Doctor's Story Viral With Fake COVID-19 Twist

Summary: False rumors were spread about a serial killer, Devender Sharma, who gave false COVID-19 positive reports to his patients to get them admitted and steal their kidneys.

Title: Former CJI Ranjan Gogoi Denies Reports Of Testing Positive For COVID-19

Summary: A false rumor was spread claiming that Jacinda Arden had visited a Hindu temple after NZ was declared COVID-19 free, even though she had gone as part of the national election campaign.

Title: Old mock funeral video viral as Muslims celebrating Amit Shah contracting coronavirus

Summary: An old mock funeral video was circulated on social Mediawith the claim that Muslims were celebrating Amit Shah getting COVID-19

Title: AYUSH Kwath or Kadha cannot ‘boost’ immunity to fight against COVID-19

Title: Coronavirus: Old video of crowded KR Market in Bengaluru shared as recent

Motive_Description: Make people think that social distancing protocols were not being followed
Summary: An old video of KR market in Bangalore was peddled as a recent video of crowds thronging the streets, not following social distancing protocols.

Title: Covid-19 : une vidéo mise hors contexte prétend montrer une distribution de vivres au Niger
Narrative_Description: Video supposedly showing a crowd fighting for food in Nigeria during the coronavirus emergency
Motive_Description: Spark indignation and outrage by making people believe the situation is so bad that people have to fight for some food in Nigeria

Summary: A video dating back to 2019 was taken out of context to claim it was showing people fighting for some food distributed freely during the coronavirus emergency

Title: Cette vidéo ne montre pas le ministre nigérian de la Santé qui s’évanouit lors d’une audition au Parlement

Motive_Description: Make people believe the situation is extremely serious and even members of the government have become infected by COVID-19

Title: Covid-19 : cette publication contient de fausses affirmations sur la gestion de la pandémie en Italie
Narrative_Description: Claims that the virus is actually bacteria and it is not as deadly as WHO would want people to believe
Motive_Description: Claim WHO has been part of a plot to let people die from an easy-to-cure disease and discredit the institution
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Guinea, bacteria, virus, WHO, autopsy, Italy
Summary: A Facebook post claimed doctors in Italy had carried out autopsies on the bodies of those who died of COVID-19 (despite WHO banning this) and had thus found out that the coronavirus is actually a bacteria, and the resulting disease being easy to cure. The post then accused WHO of causing the deaths of innocents and being part of a giant plot.

Title: FALSE: Scientists in the US have not discovered a cure for COVID-19
Narrative_Description: Article claims scientists in the US have discovered a coronavirus cure “that works 100 percent”
Motive_Description: Create False Hope about the existence of a COVID-19 cure
Summary: An article falsely claimed that Sorrento Therapeutics scientists in the US discovered a coronavirus cure "that works 100 percent." Sorrento actually discovered an antibody that is effective in blocking the virus that causes COVID-19

Title: FALSE: This post claiming that COVID-19 caused by bacterial infection is a hoax
Narrative_Description: Italian doctors discovered that COVID-19 is bacterial, not a virus
Motive_Description: Undermine the legitimacy of the WHO
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Kenya, bacteria, virus, WHO, Italy, doctors
Summary: A claim which has circulated in Other parts of the world also appeared in Kenya, falsely reporting that Italian doctors did autopsies on COVID-19 victims against the orders of the WHO, discovering that the disease is bacterial, not a virus

Title: HOAX: This Facebook page offering COVID-19 relief cash is fake
Narrative_Description: A Facebook page, bearing the name and image of Health Cabinet Secretary Mutahi Kagwe with a post claiming to offer cash relief of Ksh18,000 to Kenyans in distress as a result of the COVID-19
Motive_Description: Encourage Kenyans to send financial information
Source_Description: Facebook page Mutahi Kagwe CS Health
Summary: A Facebook page claimed to offer a fake cash relief grant from Kenya's Health Cabinet Secretary Mutahi Kagwe related to COVID-19

Title: FALSE: 19 truck drivers, not 182, tested negative for COVID-19 in Tanzania after testing positive in Kenya
Narrative_Description: Claims that 182 truck drivers who had tested positive for COVID-19 in Kenya were re-tested and found to be negative in Tanzania
Motive_Description: Target the Kenyan government for false testing
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Kenya, Tanzania, truck driver, test
Summary: Facebook posts claimed that 182 truck drivers who had tested positive for COVID-19 in Kenya were re-tested and found to be negative in Tanzania. In fact, only 19 re-tested negatives were reported

Title: HOAX: 5G technology is not linked to the COVID-19 pandemic
Narrative_Description: Claims 5G wireless technology created the COVID-19 pandemic
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about the origins of the virus
Summary: As in Other parts of the world, the claim that 5G created COVID-19 circulated in Kenya on Facebook

Title: FALSE: 25 new cases of COVID-19 announced on May 7 do not include 14 Oromo political prisoners
Narrative_Description: Claims 14 of the 25 confirmed cases of COVID-19 announced on May 7 in Ethiopia are Oromo political prisoners
Motive_Description: Claim that the Ethiopian Ministry of Health are misleading people
Summary: Online posts falsely claimed that of the 25 COVID-19 announced on May 7 in Ethiopia, 14 were Oromo political prisoners. The Ethiopian Federal Prison Commission has said no cases of COVID-19 have been confirmed among Ethiopian prisoners

Title: HOAX: This site offering relief funds to Kenyans during COVID-19 pandemic is fake
Narrative_Description: Claims that the Uhuru Kenyatta Foundation is giving out Ksh10,000 to each Kenyan as lockdown relief funds
Motive_Description: Phish for financial information
Summary: A WhatsApp phishing scam claimed that the Uhuru Kenyatta Foundation, which does not exist, was giving out relief funds to all Kenyans

Title: FALSE: Tanzania has not reported 16,467 COVID-19 positive cases
Narrative_Description: Claims Tanzania has reported 16,467 COVID-19 cases, 1,293 deaths, and 118 recoveries
Motive_Description: Call for the resignation of Tanzanian President John Pombe Magufuli
Summary: A fake Facebook page called BBC Tanzania falsely claimed that Tanzania reported 16,467 COVID-19 cases, 1,293 deaths, and 118 recoveries. This far exceeds the numbers reported by the WHO

Title: FALSE: There are no human COVID-19 vaccine trials in Kenya at the moment
Narrative_Description: Claims human testing of a COVID-19 vaccine is currently being conducted in Kenya at Kemri
Motive_Description: Claim Africans are being used as guinea pigs for vaccine trials by Europeans
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Kenya, UK, vaccine, trial, guinea pig
Summary: A Kenyan article falsely claimed that human testing of a COVID-19 vaccine was being conducted in Kenya by researchers from Oxford

Title: FALSE: Prolonged face mask use does not lower oxygen circulation in the blood
Narrative_Description: Claims prolonged use of face masks reduces the circulation of oxygen in the blood and can lead to death
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about the use of face masks
Summary: As in Other parts of the world, the false claim circulated in Kenya that prolonged use of face masks could lead to a decrease of oxygen circulation in the blood and death

Title: FALSE: Kenya did not have the highest number of COVID-19 cases in Africa on May 6
Narrative_Description: Claims Kenya had the highest cases of COVID-19 in Africa and the fifth-highest in the world on May 6
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about the severity of COVID-19 in Kenya
Summary: Tweets falsely claimed that on May 6, Kenya had the most COVID-19 cases ini Africa and the fifth-most ini the world. Both of these statements are incorrect

Title: [SALAH] Memakai Masker Dapat Timbulkan Radang Selaput Dada
Narrative_Description: Wearing a face mask can risk developing pleurisy, according to some claims in social media
Motive_Description: Incite fear of wearing mask
Summary: A purported screenshot included in the Facebook post claims a 19-year-old woman contracted pleurisy after wearing a face mask for eight hours a day, five or six days a week. The claims are false; pulmonologists say wearing a face mask does not put you at risk of developing pleurisy, nor does it deprive users of adequate oxygen or cause a surge in carbon dioxide levels.

Title: [SALAH] Surat Edaran Penolakan Rapid Test Majelis Ulama Indonesia
Narrative_Description: Covid-19 rapid test is dangerous and is designed by Indonesian Communist Party to abolish the Muslim leaders
Motive_Description: Incite fear of taking rapid test
Key_Words: Rapid test, letter, advisory, MUI (Indonesia's ulema council)
Summary: A fake advisory letter from Indonesia's ulema council urge Muslims not to take rapid test. It claims that if tested positive, the Indonesian communist party (that has long abolished) will inject poison to the patient.

Title: [SALAH] Video Animasi Penyebaran Virus Corona
Narrative_Description: A video showing how covid-19 spread through human contact
Motive_Description: Falsely educate people about coronavirus
Summary: An animated video telling how a virus spread. The video is about ebola, not abaout coronavirus

Title: Covid-19 : déclarations décontextualisées et fausses informations dans cette publication Facebook
Narrative_Description: Video claiming Senegal is carrying out fake tests for COVID-19 in order to artificially increase the amount of people infected and obtain funds
Motive_Description: Claim that the emergency in Senegal is much less serious than people believe
Summary: A video in Wolof, the most spoken language in Senegal, claimed the country was testing people with fake tests for COVID-19 in order to artificially increase the number of people infected and thus obtain funds for the emergency

Title: Cek Fakta: Tidak Benar BIN Menetapkan Peta Sebaran Covid-19 Berstatus Hitam
Narrative_Description: A graph circulated in WhatsApp showing that Indonesia's capital of Jakarta is on black zone
Motive_Description: Incite fear that the capital is under health emergency
Key_Words: BIN (Indonesia's Intelligence Agency), map, Jakarta, black zone
Summary: An infographic circulated in WhatsApp showing that Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia, is now a black zone. BIN has confirmed that they never released such data. The Indonesia's covid task force also clarified that there is no "black zone" in the covid distribution map. The black color was made to imply that it is under the worst condition.

Title: Cek Fakta: Tidak Benar Menko Luhut Sebut Arak Turunkan Angka Penderita Covid-19
Narrative_Description: The Maritime Coordinating Minister is falsely reported to have said alcohol can cure coronavirus
Motive_Description: Undermine the Maritime Coordinating Minister
Key_Words: Luhut Pandjaitan, Arak, decrease, covid-19 case
Summary: A news article reported that the Maritime Coordinating Minister said that arak from the island of Bali can cure coronavirus. The report is misleading and conflated several related stories.

Title: Cek Fakta: Tidak Benar Foto Wanita yang Sedang Divaksin adalah Putri Presiden Rusia Vladimir Putin
Narrative_Description: A photo of a woman getting vaccinated, said to be the daughter of Russia's Vladimir Putin
Motive_Description: Comparing Putin and Indonesia's president
Key_Words: Daughter, Russian president, Vladimir Putin, Vaccinated
Summary: A photo of a woman getting vaccinated, said to be the daughter of Russia's Vladimir Putin. The Facebook post then comparing Putin with Indonesia's leader in which Putin let his own daughter to be administered in the vaccine trial while the Indonesia's leader let his people taking vaccine trial from China

Title: Cek Fakta: Tidak Benar Vaksin Sinovac untuk Lawan Virus Corona Haram
Narrative_Description: Vaccine in trial from China is haram (not kosher)
Motive_Description: Incite fear of taking vaccine
Summary: A news article shared in Facebook saying that the vaccine in trial from China has yet to get halal certificate from MUI (Indonesia's Ulema Council). The caption then urging people to be cautious and refuse taking any vaccine.

Title: Cek Fakta: Tidak Benar Mengonsumsi Telur Rebus Bisa Cegah Covid-19
Narrative_Description: Eating boiled egg in the middle of the night can cure coronavirus
Motive_Description: Have people believe that boiled egg can cure coronavirus
Summary: A fake cure circulated in social Mediaand WhatsApp saying that eating boiled egg (especially at midnight) can cure coronavirus.

Title: Cek Fakta: Tidak Benar Ada 5 Orang Tewas Akibat Vaksin di Filipina
Narrative_Description: 5 people died in a city in the Phillipines after being vaccinated
Motive_Description: Incite fear of getting vaccinated
Summary: A message saying that 5 poeple died in Tarlac, the Phillipines, after being injected with a vaccine and the people that administered it could not be found. The mayor of Tarlac City denied any incident had occired

Title: Non, l’OACI n’a pas communiqué de dates de réouverture des aéroports dans le monde
Narrative_Description: List of airports that will reopen following the coronavirus emergency with the corresponding dates
Motive_Description: Have people believe there is a precise list with the dates of reopening of airports around the world following the emergency
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Senegal, Cote d'Ivoire, airport, reopen, list
Summary: A list of airports with the dates of reopening following the coronavirus emergency went viral in Senegal and Cote d'Ivoire and falsely attributed to the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), even though no such list ever existed

Title: Covid-19 : cette publication contient de fausses informations
Narrative_Description: Claims the new coronavirus is actually an old coronavirus that has been reactivated to become more dangerous, that a vaccine already exists but is hidden and that the Gates foundation has something to do with it
Motive_Description: Undermine WHO's authority by claiming it has something to do with the epidemic, together with the Gates foundation
Key_Words: Coronavirus, WHO, Gates, Foundation, vaccine, design
Summary: A post went viral in Cote d'Ivoire, claiming that the new coronavirus was actually an old virus reactivated to make it more dangerous, that WHO had a vaccine but had misteriously hidden its presence, and that the Gates foundation had something to do with all of this (citing false figures on the amounts of funding the Gates devote to WHO annually)

Title: Faux : le prix du test Covid-19 n’est pas fixé à 300 dollars américains en RDC
Primary_Country: Congo, the Democratic Republic of the
Narrative_Description: Claim that the price of a test for COVID-19 in the DRC has been set at 300 USD
Motive_Description: Criticize the government for setting the price of tests in the DRC at a very high level
Source_Description: Kudura Kasongo Muana-Luaba (spokesperson for the former President of the DRC)
Summary: A post was shared on Facebook in the DRC claiming that the price of a test for COVID-19 in the country was set at 300 USD, a very high price, while it is free for the citizens

Title: Des preuves médicales attestent que Faustin Fitika avait été testé positif en tant que premier cas de Coronavirus en RDC
Primary_Country: Congo, the Democratic Republic of the
Narrative_Description: Claim that the first confirmed case of COVID-19 in the DRC was actually paid to pretend he was positive
Motive_Description: Have people believe there is some kind of conspiracy for which the government is (at least partially) responsible
Key_Words: Coronavirus, first, case, Faustin Fitika, deny
Summary: At a TV show, the first declared case of COVID-19 in the DRC claimed he was paid by the government to claim that he had COVID-19, even though there is medical evidence that he had indeed tested positive

Title: FALSE: Education CS Prof Magoha did not announce a ban on boarding schools starting in 2021
Narrative_Description: Claims Kenya's Education Cabinet Secretary Prof George Magoha announced there will be no more boarding schools in 2021
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about potentially permanent school closures
Summary: A news article falsely claimed that Kenya's Education Cabinet Secretary Prof George Magoha announced there will be no more boarding schools in 2021. Buhere actually talked about the particular challenges posed by boarding schools, but did not suggest banning them

Title: FALSE: This Kenya Gazette notice prohibiting the sale of liquor is not legitimate
Narrative_Description: Claims Kenya’s cabinet secretary for Health, Mutahi Kagwe, has gazetted guidelines on the prohibition of the sale of alcoholic drinks
Motive_Description: Incite fear about a potential banning of alcohol sales
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Kenya, alcohol, gazette, Mutahi Kagwe
Summary: Facebook posts circulated a fake document from the Kenya Gazette claiming that the Ministry of Health intended to ban the sale of alcohol

Title: Faux, Madagascar n’a pas quitté l’OMS et n’a pas appelé les pays africains à le faire
Narrative_Description: Claim the President of Madagascar has invited African nations to leave WHO
Motive_Description: Discredit WHO by claiming that it is biased in favor of Europeans and against Africans and that they would do better without it
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Cameroon, Senegal, Madagascar, President, leave, WHO
Summary: The news went viral in Senegal, Cameroon and Other francophone countries that the President of Madagascar had invited African nations to leave WHO, while accusing the institution of being too biased in favor of Europeans and against Africans

Title: Nein, diese Grafik beweist nicht, dass das World Economic Forum die Corona-Pandemie geplant hat
Narrative_Description: Claims that a World Economic Forum graphic explicitly shows that the coronavirus was designed as part of a global governance plan
Motive_Description: Heighten suspicions about intentional design of the virus
Key_Words: Coronavirus, World Economic Forum, 5G, global governance, Kulturstudio
Summary: A Youtube channel, Kulturstudio, recently published a video that shows the narrator clicking through the WEF website, where there is an alleged 'Masterplan' that shows how coronavirus was designed and is being used to control large human populations

Title: Non, le Ghana n’a pas acheté ces ambulances dans le cadre de la lutte contre la Covid-19
Narrative_Description: Claim that Ghana's government has bought 200 ambulances to fight the coronavirus emergency
Motive_Description: Have people believe Ghana has bought 200 ambulances to prepare for the emergency
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Ghana, ambulances, buy, government, emergency
Summary: The news spread in francophone African countries such as Senegal and the Ivory Coast that neighboring Ghana had bought 200 ambulances to prepare for the coronavirus emergency, while the actual purchase dated back to 2019

Title: Studie zu Impfstoff mRNA-1273: Es stimmt nicht, dass jeder fünfte Impfproband „ernsthaft krank“ wurde
Narrative_Description: Rumors that one of the current vaccines being developed against the virus causes 1/5 of subjects to become seriously ill
Motive_Description: Bolster anti-vaccine sentiment or heighten distrust in medical science
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Germany, vaccine, test subjects, mRNA-1273
Summary: An online blogger published a post claiming that a vaccine currently being tested causes every 1 out of 5 test subjects to become seriously ill - this figure is wrong and misleading, but the blog post has been shared thousands of times on Facebook

Title: Covid-19 : l’information sur le nouveau cimetière construit en Algérie est une parodie
Narrative_Description: Claim that a new graveyard has been built in Algeria for the victims of COVID-19
Motive_Description: The news came from a parodic website, but was believed by some
Summary: The news was posted on a parodic website declaredly posting fake news that Algeria was building a new graveyard for the victims of COVID-19, but it was believed by some and shared in Senegal

Title: Covid-19: Nein, die EU hat keine Ausnahmeregelung für einen mRNA-Impfstoff erlassen
Narrative_Description: Claims spread that the EU is making an exception for a mRNA vaccine that 'contains genetically modified organisms' and 'will change our genetic code'
Motive_Description: Heighten anti-vaccine sentiments
Summary: Multiple posts spread on Facebook claim that the EU is making an exception to allow a mRNA vaccine against coronavirus that contains GMOs and can alter human genetic code - none of which is true

Title: Covid-19 : de faux propos sur les dirigeants africains attribués à Marine Le Pen
Narrative_Description: Rumors French politician Marine Le Pen has warned African governors that they will not be cured in French hospitals
Motive_Description: The author of the post admitted she wanted to criticize African governors for not caring about their own countries and their health systems
Key_Words: Coronavirus, France, Africa, governors, health, hospitals, cure
Summary: The news went viral in Senegal that French politician Marine Le Pen had warned Africans governors that they wouldn't be cured in French hospitals, as they should have taken care of their own countries' health systems

Title: Zahlreiche Falschmeldungen über Teilnehmerzahl bei Anti-Corona-Protest in Berlin
Narrative_Description: Many claims online have overexaggerated the actual number of people who attended an anti-Corona measures rally in Berline
Motive_Description: Generate anger towards those attending the protest by exaggerating how far they are flaunting safety measures
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Germany, Berlin, rally, protest, anti-Corona measures
Summary: Multiple sources online and on Facebook have been disputing and exaggerating the total figure of people attending an anti-safety measures protest in Berlin; pictures online allegedly depicting the rally have been shown to be from 2001

Title: Covid-19: cette « offre gratuite » de Netflix est fausse
Narrative_Description: Claim that Netflix is offering free subscription because of the coronavirus emergency
Motive_Description: Have people click on a link that can then steal their personal data
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Netflix, free, offer, subscription, steal, data, link
Summary: A link was largely shared on Facebook and WhatsApp with the claim that because of the coronavirus emergency, Netflix was offering a free subscription and the invitation to click on a link (which could steal the victims' personal data)

Title: FALSE: Kenya’s Central Bank has not approved the use of cryptocurrency
Narrative_Description: Claims Kenya's central bank has approved the local use of cryptocurrency and people should take advantage during the pandemic
Motive_Description: Encourage people to message users about buying into bitcoin
Key_Words: Kenya, bitcoin, pandemic, Coronavirus, central bank
Summary: An Instagram post falsely claimed that Kenya's Central Bank had approved the local use of bitcoin, encouraging people to message the poster about buying in during the pandemic

Title: FALSE HEADLINE: This article does not say Mutahi Kagwe declared Kenya COVID-19 free
Narrative_Description: Health Cabinet Secretary Mutahi Kagwe has declared Kenya COVID-19 free
Motive_Description: Create hope about Kenya being free of COVID-19
Summary: An Opera News article falsely claimed that Health Cabinet Secretary Mutahi Kagwe has declared Kenya COVID-19 free. The body of the article did not discuss this claim

Title: Coronavirus : cette vidéo ne montre pas le premier ministre chinois priant dans une mosquée
Narrative_Description: Video supposedly showing the Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang praying in a mosque for the end of COVID-19
Motive_Description: Have people believe that the Chinese PM has approached the Muslim faith in an effort to stop the coronavirus emergency
Key_Words: Coronavirus, China, Mali, PM, Li Keqiang, Prime Minister, pray, mosque, Muslim
Summary: A video of Mali's former PM visiting a mosque in Beijing was taken out of context to claim it was the Chinese Prime Minister, Li Keqiang, who had turned to the Muslim faith in an effort to stop the coronavirus emergency

Title: FALSE: Ethiopia’s federal government has not blocked COVID-19 medical supplies to Tigray Region
Narrative_Description: Claims the federal government of Ethiopia blocked medical equipment meant to support Tigray Regional State
Motive_Description: Target the Ethiopian government for excluding the Tigray Region from aid
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Ethiopia, Tigray, medical, equipment, block
Summary: A news article falsely claimed that the Ethiopian government blocked the sending of medical equipment to the Tigray Regional State. In reality, the state acknowledged receiving equipment but said it was inadequate

Title: FALSE HEADLINE: The coronavirus strain that has killed hundreds of camels in Kenya is not new
Narrative_Description: Claim a new strain of coronavirus has killed hundreds of camels in Kenya
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about new strains of COVID-19
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Kenya, strain, new, camel, kill
Summary: A website article falsely claimed that a new strain of coronavirus killed hundreds of camels in Kenya. The disease, MERS‐CoV, was first identified in Saudi Arabia in 2012

Title: FALSE: Novavax’s trial COVID-19 vaccine has not been released to the public yet
Narrative_Description: Says US-based biotech company Novavax has released a COVID-19 vaccine
Motive_Description: Create hope about a COVID-19 vaccine
Summary: An article in Kenya falsely claimed that the US-based biotech company Novavax released a COVID-19 vaccine. Novavax actually released test results on a vaccine

Title: HOAX: Samsung is not running a promotion for students affected by COVID-19
Narrative_Description: Claims Samsung is running a giveaway to help students who have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic
Motive_Description: Phishing scam to get people to message a fake page
Summary: A fake Facebook page advertised a Samsung giveaway for students impacted by COVID-19, encouraging people to message the page

Title: FALSE HEADLINE: Kenya has not blocked flights from Europe and the US
Narrative_Description: Kenya has blocked flights from Europe and the US of America
Motive_Description: Incite fear about the limiting of travel into Kenya
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Kenya, flight, US, Europe, block
Summary: An article from Kenya Today had a false headline claiming that Kenya had blocked flights from Europe and the US. Travelers from these areas will have to undergo quarantine

Title: FALSE: Coconut does not cure COVID-19
Narrative_Description: claims scientists from the Philippines have discovered that oil extracted from coconuts can cure COVID-19
Motive_Description: Create hope about a COVID-19 cure
Summary: An article on Opera News falsely claimed that scientists in the Philippines discovered that coconut can cure COVID-19

Title: FALSE: President Magufuli did not order a plane carrying a Kenyan delegation to Mkapa’s funeral service to turn back
Narrative_Description: Claims Tanzania’s President John Magufuli ordered a plane carrying a delegation from Kenya to the funeral of former president Benjamin Mkapa to turn back
Motive_Description: Claim the incident was a result of Kenya’s criticism of Tanzania for hiding information regarding the coronavirus situation in the country
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Kenya, Tanzania, funeral, plane, criticism
Summary: An article in Kenya claimed that Tanzania’s President John Magufuli ordered a plane carrying a delegation from Kenya to the funeral of former president Benjamin Mkapa to turn back after Kenya criticized Tanzania's COVID-19 response. The plane actually turned back for mechanical reasons

Title: FALSE: This image claiming to show students returning to school with babies after COVID-19 is misleading
Narrative_Description: Claims a photo shows students in Tanzania returning to school with babies after the lifting of restrictions to contain COVID-19
Motive_Description: Suggest that young women had babies during the COVID-19 lockdown
Summary: An image circulated with the claim that it showed young women returning to school after the COVID-19 lockdown with babies and young children. The photo is from a different context

Title: FALSE HEADLINE: The ‘COVID-19 cure’ that Machakos County received from Tanzania has not been proven to work
Narrative_Description: Claims that Machakos County in Kenya has received bottles of a COVID-19 cure from Tanzania
Motive_Description: Create hope about a COVID-19 cure
Source_Description: Machakos County Governor Dr Alfred Mutua
Summary: In Kenya, Machakos County Governor Dr Alfred Mutua claimed to have received a COVID-19 cure from Tanzania. The medicine, Baycaro, does not treat COVID-19

Title: FALSE: Scott’s Emulsion does not protect against COVID-19
Narrative_Description: Claims that Scott’s Emulsion provides immunity against COVID-19
Motive_Description: Suggest some people are immune to COVID-19
Summary: A Facebook post falsely suggested that taking Scott's Emulsion (a vitamin supplement) made kids from the 1990s immune to COVID-19

Title: FALSE: Reports that the Uganda Police Force will arrest couples who don’t practise social distancing are false
Narrative_Description: Says Uganda Police Force will arrest couples who do not practise social distancing
Motive_Description: Stoke fear about couples being arrested for not social distancing
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Uganda, police, arrest, couples, social distancing
Summary: Facebook posts attribeud a false claim to Police Spokesperson Fred Enanga claiming Ugandan police would arrest couples who did not practice social distancing

Title: FALSE: Uganda does not have more COVID-19 recoveries than confirmed cases
Narrative_Description: Claims Uganda has more COVID-19 recoveries than the number of confirmed cases
Motive_Description: Criticize government actors for fake COVID-19 case counts
Summary: Social Mediaposts claimed that Uganda's number of COVID-19 recoveries was higher than the number of cases, but recoveries include Ugandans, non-Ugandans and refugee

Title: ES FALSO QUE A LOS FAMILIARES DE PERSONAS CON COVID-19 “SOLO LES AVISARÁN QUE MURIÓ”
Narrative_Description: Claim that minors with covid-19 are taken from their parents and not allowed to say goodbye if they pass away
Motive_Description: Spread fear about process to treat minors infected with covid-19
Key_Words: Coronavirus, minors, relatives, goodbye, isolation, treatment
Summary: An image circulated social networks detailing an incorrect process of treating minors infected with covid-19 in Guatemala. The post included claims that infected minors are taken away from their parents, cannot say goodbye if they die, and that relatives will not be allowed to attend a funeral.

Title: ES IMPRECISO DECIR QUE LA BANCADA SEMILLA VOTÓ EN CONTRA DE LA LEY DE EMERGENCIA POR LA COVID-19
Narrative_Description: Claim that the Semilla Movement's Congressional bench voted against the Covid-19 Emergency Law
Motive_Description: Discredit the Semilla Movement political party
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Semilla Movement, Emergency Law, Congress, absent
Summary: False claims spread via social Mediathat, because a few Semilla Movment members withdrew from a congressional session when representatives voted in favor of a Covid-19 Emergency Law, the Semilla Movement's bench as a whole had voted against the law. However, four members of the bench were present and voted in favor.

Title: ¡BULO! // J. RODAS NO SOLICITÓ QUE LAS PRUEBAS DE COVID-19 SEAN PAGADAS POR LA CIUDADANÍA
Narrative_Description: Claim that judge and notary Jordán Rodas Andrade demaded that covid-19 tests be paid for by citizens
Motive_Description: Spread false info. about political figure
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Nación Libre Gt, Jordán Rodas Andrade, tests, citizens, paid
Summary: A facebook profile spread fake information that Human Rights Ombudsman, Jordán Rodas Andrade, demanded that covid-19 tests be paid for by the citizens.

Title: ¡BULO! // “PLAN REACTIVACIÓN ECONÓMICA DE GUATEMALA”
Narrative_Description: False economic recovery plan for Guatemala
Motive_Description: Provides hope-inducing timeline for economic and social recovery
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Economic Recovery Plan, phases, Guatemala
Summary: Posts circulated social Mediadetailing the phases of an alleged economic recovery plan for Guatemala

Title: MINISTERIO DE SALUD ASEGURA QUE NO HAY COLONIAS CON CORDÓN SANITARIO EN CIUDAD DE GUATEMALA
Narrative_Description: Speculation about a sanitary cordon in Guatemla City
Motive_Description: Creates fear about community cases necessitating a sanitary cordon in Guatemala city
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Sanitary Cordon, Guatemala City, community cases
Summary: Speculation led to a mention on Twitter in which someone questioned whether there was a sanitary cordon implemented by the Ministry of Health in Guatemala City.

Title: ¡BULO! // CACIF NIEGA HABER CONVOCADO PARA CARAVANA EN EL OBELISCO
Narrative_Description: A claim to reject the total closure of the country was falsely attributed to Cacif (the Coordinating Committee of Agricultural, Commercial, Industrial and Financial Associations
Motive_Description: Target Cacif through falsely attributed political statement
Summary: An image spread via social Mediafalsely attributed a call for the "rejection of the total closure of the country and the State of Public Calamity" to Cacif, the Coordinating Committee of Agricultural, Commercial, Industrial and Financial Associations.

Title: NO, NO CERRARÁN LOS HOSPITALES TEMPORALES
Narrative_Description: False claim that Juan Nájera, director of the Quetzaltenango Health Area, said that temporary hospitals will stop treating covid-19 patients
Motive_Description: Create fear over closing of temporary hospitals
Key_Words: Coronavirus, temporary hospitals, close, Quetzaltenango, Juan Nájera
Summary: Hoax spread via Facebook that the director of the Quetzaltenango Health Area said that temporary hospitals, which are used to care for covid-19 patients, will stop treating those patients and/or close.

Title: VERDADERO // GIAMMATTEI SÍ FUE AL HOSPITAL, PERO A UN CHEQUEO
Narrative_Description: False claims that Guatemlan President, Alejandro Giammattei, was admitted in an emergency to a hospital due to a delicate state of health
Motive_Description: False Reporting of video that surfaced
Source_Description: Coronavirus Guatemala, An0nymous Guatemala, and A Diario GT Twitter accounts
Summary: Two Twitter accounts falsely claimed that Guatemalan President, Alejandro Giammattei, had been admitted in an emergency to a hospital due to being in a delcate state of health; based this off of a video of his car parked otuside of a hospital during a general medical check-up.

Title: QUÉ SABEMOS DEL VIDEO DE UN ENTIERRO SIN CADÁVER EN SOLOLÁ
Narrative_Description: A coffin arrived empty at a funeral in Sololá
Motive_Description: Misunderstanding of situation and video contents
Summary: A video circulated Twitter and Facebook spreading that the coffin of a deceased young man arrived empty at his funeral.

Title: Afghan herbalist clinic closed over quack coronavirus ‘cure’
Narrative_Description: Corona Virus Clinic closed
Motive_Description: Criticize government
Summary: Afghan who make coronavirus drop clinic closed by Government

Title: Afghan Gov’t Warns Against Popular But Unproven Coronavirus Treatment
Narrative_Description: healer claimed he has found a cure for treating COVID-19
Motive_Description: Drops of Covid-19 vaccine
Key_Words: Healer,claimed, found a cure for treating COVID-19
Summary: healer claimed he has found a cure for treating COVID-19

Title: Desperate for Any Coronavirus Care, Afghans Flock to Herbalist’s ‘Vaccine’

Key_Words: Coronavirus, Italy, gloves, WHO, wash, hands
Summary: Several Italian newspapers misreported the news that WHO had specifically included in its guidelines for COVID-19 the suggestion to wash one's hands often rather than using gloves, especially in public, by saying that WHO had abruptly changed its point of view on the matter. This was untrue as the institution had been suggesting that since March.

Title: Coronavirus. Immuni e la «prigioniera»: facciamo chiarezza per chi non ha letto le istruzioni

Key_Words: Coronavirus, Italy, Immuni, app, quarantine, contact tracing
Summary: An Italian newspaper blamed the Italian contact tracing app "Immuni" of automatically leading to the self-isolation of a woman who had discovered through it that she had been in contact with a person positive to COVID-19. It was doctors, however, who took the decision, the app is voluntary and any delay in receiving the test is due to the healthcare system in general.

Summary: A paper, not subject to peer review, linked a decrease in infant deaths during the epidemic (not based on data, but on "anecdotal evidence" by some doctors), to less vaccines being distributed to children, even though there is no evidence in favor of the claim. The document also went viral among anti-vax groups in Italy.

Title: Coronavirus, fare il vaccino antinfluenzale ci mette a rischio contagio?

The video, however, shows a child in Russia being taken to hospital in April and the claims are false.

Title: Зараженные бананы, миллионы инфицированных и целебная водка: приморцы пересылают фейковые сообщения о коронавирусе (ОПРОС)

Key_Words: Coronavirus, vaccines, Dolores Cahill, no-vax, dogs, serum, influenza
Summary: A video by no-vax supporter and Irish far-right political figure Dolores Cahill emerged, where she claimed, among Other things, that the new coronavirus had probably infected men through anti-influenza vaccines, given that these vaccines are supposedly obtained with the use of the serum of dogs and dogs might carry the virus

Title: Coronavirus. Le ASL e il complotto dei falsi positivi: i casi di Arezzo e Montevarchi

Primary_Country: Congo, the Democratic Republic of the
Narrative_Description: Claim that the epidemic has ended in May and that precautionary measures such as social distancing or wearing masks only serve to delay collective immunity
Motive_Description: Discredit governments and pharmaceutical companies by accusing them of delaying the reaching of collective immunity in order to sell vaccines
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Congo, precautionary, measures, masks, distancing, vaccines, immunity
Summary: The rumor went viral in the DRC and was discussed on social Mediathat the COVID-19 epidemic had already ended in May and that precautionary measures such as wearing masks or social distancing were only being implemented in order to delay herd immunity and sell vaccines in the future

Title: Coronavirus. Secondo Barillari Nature dice che il vaccino contro il SARS-CoV2 non serve. Forse non lo ha capito
Narrative_Description: Claim that any vaccine against COVID-19 would be useless as the virus is subject to too frequent mutations, and that the famous review Nature has published an article on this
Motive_Description: Argue in favor of the anti-vax movement that a vaccine against COVID-19 would be useless and only serves economic purposes
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Italy, Davide Barillari, Lazio, vaccine, useless, no-vax
Summary: Davide Barillari, member of the Regional Council of the Lazio region in Italy, attributed to the periodical Nature the claim that a vaccine against COVID-19 would be useless, as the virus is subject to very frequent mutations and is therefore unpredictable, even though there is no evidence supporting this and Nature never published articles on this

Title: Coronavirus. La copertina bufala del Le Parisien con il governatore De Luca (e la rettifica di Lucia Annunziata)
Narrative_Description: Cover of "the Parisien" attributing to the President of Italian Region Campania the title of "King of Italy" for his good handling of the coronavirus emergency
Motive_Description: Support Vicnenzo de Luca and praise his handling of the coronavirus emergency
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Italy, Campania, Vincenzo de Luca, King, emergency
Summary: A fake cover of French newspaper "le Parisien" attributing to the governor of Italian region Campania, Vincenzo de Luca, the title of "King of Italy" for his good handling of the coronavirus emergency was believed to be true by many, including the presenter of a famous political talk show on TV, who later admitted the mistake

Title: Coronavirus. Se il virus SARS-CoV2 si indebolisce significa che è artificiale come ha detto Zaia? No!
Narrative_Description: Claim that if the virus gets weaker with time, it is proof that it was artificially designed
Motive_Description: Support the conspiracy theory for which the virus was artificially created by someone, with some obscure purpose
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Italy, Veneto, Luca Zaia, artificial, design, weak
Summary: The governor of the Italian Veneto region, Luca Zaia, claimed during a press conference that if coronavirus gets weaker with time it is evidence that it was, somehow, artificially designed. However, there is no evidence that the virus is getting weaker and even if it was, it wouldn't prove that it was artificially created in a lab.

Title: Coronavirus. Il Governo ha ordinato di non fare le autopsie sui morti Covid-19? Si potevano e si possono fare
Narrative_Description: Claim that the Italian government, during the emergency, prohibitied autopsies on those who died of COVID-19
Motive_Description: Discredit the Italian government and its handling of the emergency by suggesting it had some obscure reason for banning autopsies
Key_Words: Coronavirus, Italy, autopsy, doctors, ban, government
Summary: The image of a communication by the Italian government supposedly banning autopsies was shared in Italy, accompanied by the claim that the government had some obscure reason for the ban, which possibly delayed new discoveries in the fight against the virus. After thorough reading, however, it could be understood that the communication was not banning autopsies.

Title: فى محافظة الإسكندرية.. ما حقيقة عزل قرية "المسيرى" بسبب فيروس كورونا؟
Narrative_Description: Claim that Egyptian village "Massery" will be locked down and quarantined because of the spread of coronavirus

Summary: Rumor that Egyptian village "Massery" will be locked down and quarantined because of the spread of coronavirus. But the rumor was denied by authorities

Summary: Fake infographic circulated in Spain claiming that the Spanish PM Oedro Sanchez and his vice presidents all tested positive for coronavirus, a situation in which the Spanish constitution purportedly calls for the king to dissolve both the parliament and "the Courts" and set up new elections.

Summary: Anonymous WhatsApp audio message (purportedly from an unidentified worker at the Gregorio Marañón Hospital in Madrid) circulated in Spain claiming that the virus sticks to nail polish, creams, make up, and jewelry.

Summary: Claims that coronavirus couldn't spread in Africa or India because there is less diversity of (warm-blooded) mammals compared to China, and though there is more biodiversity in Africa compared to India, the populationd density is lower

Title: Masques : ce visuel partagé par des gendarmes sur les risques de transmission du Covid-19 est-il exact ?

Key_Words: Coronavirus, wear, masks, social, distancing, Vosges, Gendarmerie, graphic
Summary: The Gendarmerie of the French department of Vosges shared a graphic on twitter that had already spread in Other countries, showing the risk of being infected with COVID-19 (in percentage terms) associated with different measures (wearing a mask, social distancing, both). The percentages, however, were confusing and probably invented as they could not refer to any scientific study on the matter.

Title: Coronavirus et rentrée scolaire : la France est-elle à la traîne par rapport à d'autres pays européens, comme l'affirme une publication sur Facebook ?

Summary: A graphic comparing the French government's handling of the school system in the aftermath of the epidemic to that of neighboring countries such as Italy, Spain and Ireland was widely shared on Facebook. Its criticism, however, was deceptive as France had designed a protocol on the reopening of schools precisely like those countries.
